Moreover, the prederivator \(\mathbf{Ho}(\mathcal{V})\) is then a Grothendieck derivator; see [Ciso3, Thm. 6.11]. This means in particular that, for any functor between small categories \(u : I \longrightarrow J\), the functor \(u^*\) has a left adjoint

\[(3.2.13.2) \quad \mathbf{L}u_{\#} : \mathbf{Ho}(\mathcal{V})(I) \longrightarrow \mathbf{Ho}(\mathcal{V})(J)\]

as well as a right adjoint

\[(3.2.13.3) \quad \mathbf{R}u_* : \mathbf{Ho}(\mathcal{V})(I) \longrightarrow \mathbf{Ho}(\mathcal{Y})(J)\]

(in the case where \(J = e\) is the terminal category, \(\mathbf{L}u_{\#}\) is the homotopy colimit functor, while \(\mathbf{R}u_*\) is the homotopy limit functor).

If \(\mathcal{V}\) and \(\mathcal{V}'\) are two model categories, a morphism of derivators

\[\Phi : \mathbf{Ho}(\mathcal{V}) \longrightarrow \mathbf{Ho}(\mathcal{V}') \]

is simply a morphism of 2-functors, that is, the data of functors

\[\Phi_I : \mathbf{Ho}(\mathcal{V})(I) \longrightarrow \mathbf{Ho}(\mathcal{\mathcal{V}'})(I)\]

together with coherent isomorphisms

\[u^*(\Phi_J(F)) = \Phi_I(u^*(F))\]

for any functor \(u : I \longrightarrow J\) and any presheaf \(F\) on \(J\) with values in \(\mathcal{V}\) (see [Ciso3, p. 210] for a precise definition).

Such a morphism \(\Phi\) is said to be continuous if, for any functor \(u : I \longrightarrow J\), and any object \(F\) of \(\mathbf{Ho}(\mathcal{V})(I)\), the canonical map

\[(3.2.13.4) \quad \Phi_J \mathbf{R}u_*(F) \longrightarrow \mathbf{R}u_* \Phi_I(F)\]
